awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Document Layout and Formatting Helper for Blind Authors
awd_abstract_narration:
Most work on computer interaction for blind people focuses on these users as consumers, rather than creators, of information.  Work on document creation specifically intended for blind people mainly concentrates on supporting general tasks associated with writing documents rather than on document formatting and layout, even though there is evidence that blind authors' documents are treated dismissively when they do not live up to "expected" standards of document presentation.  Many blind authors therefore rely on sighted people to check their documents; consequently, they cannot be as productive as their sighted peers.  The PI's goal in this project is to facilitate independence for blind authors in producing documents that meet the presentation standards expected by sighted readers.   To these ends, the PI will develop an impact-weighted taxonomy of common document presentation errors of blind authors.  She will explore blind authors' mental models and strategies for learning and coping, and how these models and strategies contribute to the success of independent document formatting and layout activities.   And she will investigate the content-sharing and voting dynamics of blind authors.  These findings will enable her to implement an integrated solution to document preparation for blind authors in the form of a Microsoft Word compatible formatting and layout checker, as well as a fix to the compatibility problems between Word's grammar and spell checkers and commonly used screen readers.   And she will develop an accessible content-sharing environment for blind authors with an interface for sighted help from Amazon Mechanical Turk.  To achieve her goals the PI will employ, among other techniques, participatory design with blind users and controlled experiments for investigating real-time non-visual presentation of grammar, spelling, formatting and layout statuses, errors and corrections (including through the use of haptic feedback and spatial sound).

Broader Impacts:  This research will naturally involve blind persons at almost all stages.  Project outcomes will reduce the necessity for blind authors to rely on sighted help, thus affording increased independence and productivity to members of this community.  The work will likely prove of value to the general population as well, for whom non-visual document presentation information can be of benefit in eyes-busy or phone-based interactions.  The PI will conduct numerous educational and outreach activities in conjunction with this project, including distribution of the software tools developed to centers and schools for blind and visually impaired persons, and development of a multidisciplinary and multilevel (undergraduate and graduate) course aimed at both psychology and computer engineering students on "Designing Socio-technical Systems for People with Special Needs."

por.por_cntn:
Document presentation can be as important as its content in professional and academic environments. People with blindness are aware that poorly-formatted documents (i.e. containing presentation errors such as inconsistent font size or type, or incorrectly aligned text) may be treated dismissively. Unfortunately, formatting documents can be a daunting task for blind authors due to lack of non-visual information about document presentation in word processors and screen readers, causing them to seek help from sighted people for checking or creating documents, resulting in delays and reliance on the availability of sighted assistance. 

We designed and carried out a series of studies to investigate the best way to facilitate independence for blind authors in producing documents that meet the presentation standards expected by sighted readers. The first study investigated the presentation standards of sighted readers. In parallel, we collected documents that were independently created by blind persons. After anonymizing the documents, we performed studies with Amazon’s Mechanical Turk to extract presentation errors in the documents. The errors were then classified by three independent coders in a follow-up study. These errors formed the basic of the functions of a Microsoft Word add-on, which checks for presentation errors in an existing document and provide the information in a blind-friendly manner through participatory design process with blind persons and instructors. As a side product, we also produced templates for various academic and professional purposes (resume, scientific paper, etc.) for blind authors to start a document that minimizes the potential of presentation errors. The tool and templates were then evaluted by a cohort of blind authors in long-term natural setting.

Our study uncovered many new findings. We gained a formal understanding of the document formatting expected by sighted readers. We gathered a taxonomy of presentation errors and twenty-two system requirements for document presentation tools for blind authors that may be generalized for other tools designed to help people with blindness, which can definitely benefit developers of such tools. We gained insight into the information the tool should provide and when and how it should provide it so that it helps blind authors understand the current formatting and their formatting errors without adding to their cognitive load. We also produced an open-source document presentation checking and correction tool, in addition to a series of templates that can help blind authors produce the document formats that are expected by sighted readers. The tool itself contains tutorial, especially to inform congenitally blind persons how the different types of fonts look like and how to run the shortcuts to gain access to various functionalities of the tool.
